content.html: Some of the most easy-to-understand characters in One piece is Roronova Zoro. He is portrayed as a personality who wants to be the world's greatest swordsman.

He is also driven by an aim to be the best at what he does like the rest of the Straw hat crew. It is a trait that can be seen across the straw hat crew even though Nico Robin and Soul King do not explicitly mention them, their actions and hard work make it evident.
Zoro seems to be a calm level headed character who wants very few things to get going but overdoes all of them.
He sleeps a lot, drinks a lot, and trains a lot.
Another person who seems to keep his word. Some of the only characters which Luffy directly convinces to join by initially rejects but Luffy seems to be more persistent and finally, Zoro gives in.

If he sees an enemy with a sword rest assured Zoro will be the one fighting that character and all the free time that Zoro has would be spent on sleeping and the reminder on training, drinking, or finding the way back after getting lost.

For a strong-willed person who trains every chance he gets, he seems to be the one without a sense of direction. And every time Sanji picks on Zoro, they both start to fight. Almost like the relationship that Zoro and Sanji have is through fighting, taunting, and making fun of each other.

They even seem to be fighting sometimes while fighting their enemy. Zoro is the type who gets annoyed with Sanji and somehow that seems to take priority over defeating the enemy even though for a very short time.

An interesting character indeed but interestingly is never seen to be drunk like a fish ever. A fast learner when it comes to sword fighting by motivating himself to be increasingly better every single time and always finding a way of increasingly tougher situations like when fighting Mr 1 in Alabasta.

His integrity shows when he takes his captains' words as gospel, in fact, more than any other member of the crew and when Usopp fights with Luffy in Water Seven and leaves the group. It is Zoro who reminds Luffy that any member of the crew who disobeys the Captain cannot be taken back as it would undermine the captain.

Luffy and Sanji immediately seem to understand where Zoro is coming from and agree that if the first thing Usopp says when seeing Luffy is an apology they would take him in and when the Thousand Sunny leaves the shore without Usopp everyone is disappointed that Usopp never wanted to join his crew. But Usopp typical of his character starts with his lies which Zoro, Luffy, and Sanji conveniently do not hear until Usopp apologizes.

It shows that at the same time they are willing to pardon Usopp for his naive lies as they know, trust and miss Usopp. It all shows how much they value their crew and regard them as friends or even family.

Another instance when Zoro shows his character is when he begs the current world's best swordsman Hawk-Eye to train him because Luffy requested all of his crew to become stronger and meet them in Sabaody Arc. Hawk-Eye gets disappointed in Zoro initially when he begs but understands that he is doing it for someone else so he agrees to train him. The irony in all of this is that Zoro wants to be trained by Hawk Eye for Zoro to be the world's best swordsman by killing Hawk Eye.

Zoro wants to be stronger and sucks up his ego because of his loyalty to the captain and does what is necessary to become stronger with what he has at that time! If it is the enemy who has to train him so be it!
All these moments convey Zoro as a person who is a very strong, fiercely loyal, and trustable person. There is no mystery there.

The extent of closeness to Sanji is shown in the thriller bark while encountering Kuma. When Zoro realizes that there is a no-win situation and they are doomed to fail and Kuma is going to arrest Luffy. Zoro sacrifices himself instead of Luffy and strikes a bargain with Kuma. Sanji realizing all of this comes to Zoroâ€™s rescue and Zoro bashes Sanji unconscious and indeed successfully negotiated his sacrifice which leaves Zoro on the brink of death. The extent of the injury is evident when he needs to be taken care of by Negative Hollow after so many days and is required to recuperate for two weeks before starting to be trained by Hawk Eye.

Zoro is ready to sacrifice himself for the sake of the whole crew and a person who is willing to sacrifice himself for others is the highest virtue possible among all the virtue. And it is this character that makes him the most reliable character in all of the straw hat crew along with the protagonist Luffy.
His strength as a personality and reliability is shown when Usopp leaves the crew in Water Seven and Zoro is the first to recover and move on while providing a strong place to rely on for others.

All these traits make him one of the most easy-to-understand, clear characters whose traits would ensure that he would indeed one day become the world's best swordsman. What is the use of the world's best swordsman if he is constantly not putting himself in danger for the betterment of everyone around him and as an extension the whole world? And such a strong person should also be reliable, loyal, and strong and could see through the lies.
